EVP-Global Gas & Liquefied Natural Gas Business

plist.p: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. It's a very – it's a pleasure for us to welcome you here this morning, with Isabelle Kocher, Jean-François Cirelli and everyone else from the group. We're going to presenting with you the results from 2011, as well as the strategy and outlook for GDF SUEZ for 2012.

We'd like to thank you first for having – with still the cold weather to come along and join us this morning. This is good news for energy producers such as us since we sell electricity and gas. It's also a challenge because we are constantly outperforming our previous records in France and in Europe.

And our teams are working hard to make sure that we have a steady supply of Russian gas in order to serve all of our customers. We have a gas portfolio. It's one of the most diverse in the world, and this is something that says a lot about how much security of supply we can provide. Jean-François will tell us a bit more about that a little bit later on.

This morning, we're going to be presenting to you the key figures and highlights of 2011. In particular, we'll be talking about our strong international growth in gas and electricity. Isabelle will be speaking to you in a more detailed manner about our accounts for 2011. And we'll be hearing about our optimization of assets, and Jean-François will be talking about progress that we've made in our long-term supply contracts and negotiations, the end of the freeze on gas rates in France, and also the establishment of our new business line, Energy Europe, for managing our European business. But let's begin by looking at what happened in 2011.

2011 was a year that was of great strategic importance for the group. We finalized the merger with International Power, which was the second-largest merger and acquisition of 2010 when we announced it. So, it was – the deal was closed in 2011.

It's also a year during which we reached an agreement with the Chinese sovereign fund, CIC, which is a real premier for a European group. So, we have a very promising outlook in Asia which is one of the most dynamic parts of the world. And this constitutes a slight shift in the center of gravity of our activity, specifically when it comes to LNG.

So, both of these operations and transactions are part and parcel of our industrial and commercial strategy. It is the acceleration of our development in the emerging countries. We have decided to move in this direction and we've done so in a rather spectacular fashion, with this shift in our LNG business towards Asia Pacific, with new contracts and new projects in China, India, Korea, Malaysia and Australia.

2011 also was a year in which the general financial and business environment was impacted by some external events. It was a difficult year in terms of overall economic growth especially in Europe. It was also a year with major changes effort. We saw that with the nuclear disaster at Fukushima.

Whoever would have been able to predict, for example, just how quickly the Arab Spring would spread? Who could forget the euro crisis and what happened in Fukushima, just underscores how important it is for our societies to have a proper energy mix.

Now, for our group, 2011 was a year that was exceptionally warm. It's easy to forget that now because it's very cold today, but 2011 was the warmest year of the century so far, and we also had to contend with a freeze on gas rates in France in the second half of the year. Despite these elements that had direct impact on the group, the group's results are solid in 2011. We're up 7% with overall sales. EBITDA is up 9.5% to €16.5 billion. Net income group share is €4 billion. Free cash flow is at almost €9 billion, €8.8 billion, compared to €7 billion last year.

Now, one of the things that we can say is that we've paid particular attention to the financial structure of GDF SUEZ. Our net debt stands at €37.6 billion. It's gone down by €4 billion compared to the level that we had at the end of 2010 on a pro forma basis, prior to the integration of International Power. So, we have met all of our financial objectives that we'd set for ourselves for 2011.

Let me just remind you that all of the targets that we've set were on the basis of a hypothesis of no major regulatory or macroeconomic changes and normal average weather conditions. Now, if we exclude the abnormal weather conditions and the gas rate freeze in France, our EBITDA would actually stand at €17.4 billion which is at the upper end of the range that we had stated in our guidance. And our earnings per share was at €2.1, on par with what we saw in 2010. We've continued with our industrial development with gross CapEx at about €11 billion which is in line with our guidance. So, we are continuing with our industrial development.

We also have a program for optimizing our portfolio. This is what we announced when we merged with International Power. We announced this in March 2011 when the deal was closed. The target was €10 billion over a three-year period, 2011 to 2013. We're off to a very good start because we've already made two-thirds of the way towards reaching that target by the end of 2011.

Net debt is 2.3 times EBITDA, so it's lower than it was – than our target of 2.5. And it constitutes an improvement compared to where we stood on a pro-forma basis at the end of 2010 with International Power. Our gearing is under 50%, so we have one of the strongest financial structures in the entire sector or industry. We will propose to the general shareholders' meeting in April a dividend of €1.5 per share which is on at par with what we had in 2011. This is a balance to be paid out of €0.67 in order to top up what we had already given by way of an adjustment of €0.83 in November.

Now one of the priorities for GDF SUEZ is sort of a moral contract that we have in markets and with our shareholders. We've decided to have a stable dividend policy. Now since the merger, the group has focused on three main components, first of all, an ordinary dividend payout but also exceptional dividend payouts and share buybacks. Between 2000 and 2011, the average – the ordinary dividend has gone up, on average, by 5% per year. In 2009, we also paid out an exceptional dividend of €0.8 per share, and we bought back 74 million of our own shares between 2008 and 2011 which is the equivalent of €2.4 billion, including €200 million being spent on the most recent chapter of that share buyback that we announced in September 2011.

As you can see, despite the crisis, GDF SUEZ has provided an attractive return on their investments to our shareholders, and this is one of our group's priorities. I would like to say that we'd like to continue to pay our shareholders our dividends in two payments with an advanced payment before the end of the year and the balance when the final accounts are closed.

Now, the group has committed to reaching not just financial targets but also industrial targets. This is our vision for the corporation. We want to be able to ensure our long-term development, and this is why we're also banking on sustainable development. We are a group that can provide solutions for its customers. It can create jobs, and it makes investments. I'm not going to go into all of the details of our sustainable development objectives. But when we presented our annual results in 2010, we decided to announce sustainable development targets for 2015 when it comes to renewable energy sources, biodiversity, health and safety, energy mix and training, employee shareholdings and hiring. So, on the one hand, we have an industrial project, but we also have a genuine human and social project as well. And this is something that will guarantee future growth regardless of changes in the outside world.

Today, we can now give you progress report on these targets as you can see on the screen. For each one of these indicators, we are well positioned in order to meet the targets that we've set for ourselves for 2015.

Let's now go back to what happened in 2011 and look at some of the major stages that we went through in our business development. Our strategy has three main thrusts. Firstly, international development in the emerging countries. Our target here is to reach 150 gigawatts of installed capacity by 2016 with more than 50% of it that is 90 gigawatts outside of Europe. We're also going to continue to consolidate or integrate our positions in Europe. Jean-François will tell us little bit about that later on, and that is why we've created the Energy Europe, the business line.

Thirdly, we are going to be strengthening infrastructures, energy, and environmental services. These are business lines which generate high levels of recurring income. And you know that our objective here is to have a balanced portfolio of activity. We also want to make sure that we can develop the businesses that give us secure returns on investment and secure cash flow on a recurring basis.

Our industrial development in fact are part and parcel of this strategy. Let me just mention some examples. And you can see some of them on the slide. In electricity, we have about 5 gigawatts that came into service in 2011. I would like to mention, in particular Ras Laffan in Qatar, which is the largest in the gulf and the second largest in the Middle East. The largest one is one that we built in Saudi Arabia last year. We've also opened Estreito in Brazil. In France, we've gone beyond the threshold of 1 gigawatt of installed wind power, which means that GDF SUEZ is the confirmed leader in this business in France.

In gas, GDF SUEZ has reached a strategic partnership with the CNP Assurances, a Caisse des Dépôts consortium for gas transport. We've also purchased five underground natural gas storage facilities in Germany, bringing our total storage capacity to 12.5 billion cubic meters. And in today's context, you can see just how important it is to be able to store a large amount of gas in order to provide security of supply whenever the weather gets very cold. It also affords us greater flexibility on a European energy market that is increasingly volatile.

2011 was also a year in which we had two gas pipelines come on stream, providing gas to European markets, Medgaz in the Mediterranean and Nord Stream in the North Sea and the group is a shareholder in that gas pipeline.

Now, when it comes to services, we've won many new contracts, many new accounts in water supply and waste management in Australia, Spain, France. And in heating networks, the group has continued growing that business. It's a very dynamic business. We have 12 heating network contracts that we've won this – in 2011 in France and in the UK. More generally speaking, the group in 2011 has strengthened its position on growth markets with the successful integration of International Power. This integration took place in record time as the closing took place less than a year ago, and the integration is now a daily reality and we are starting to tap the synergies already. We've also signed a strategic partnership with the Chinese sovereign fund, CIC, which is a very special relationship, something that will help all of our businesses and also our geographical position in Asia Pacific.

2011 has also been a year in which we're prepared for future growth. And as I said, we're setting our sights on the growth markets around the world, in particular, the emerging countries. On this slide, you can see some key figures on some of the operations that we have been involved in or that are under way for the development of the group, in Latin America, for example.

We have 5.5 gigawatts that are currently being built in Brazil and in Peru. We have the acquisition of Térmika in Chile. The group now has, as a result, a strong foothold to have the sustainable development of its businesses in the region in the field of energy efficiency. In the Middle East, the group is currently building 4 gigawatts of electrical power. We also have been designated preferred bidder in Kuwait for a 1.5 – 1,500-megawatt plant. This is an announcement that was just made a few days ago. We also have a contract that we've won in Qatar for a waste-water treatment in Doha and the Al Dur desalination plant which is currently being built in Bahrain.

When it comes to E&P, we are currently still working on building the Touat gas field in Algeria. In Asia Pacific, the group has been very active. 2.9 kilowatts are being built in electricity generation. In E&P, I would like to mention a recent discovery in the gas field of Jangkrik in Indonesia and a very promising results for the license for Absheron in Azerbaijan. 2011 was also a year in which we continued with a very – with a winning strategy of developing our activities in liquefied natural gas.

Let me just focus on this a bit. One of the main challenges in gas markets today is very rapid growth of demand for LNG in Asia which is a region that is growing very quickly. LNG is a critical feature to fuel growth in that part of the world and GDF SUEZ is in a good position in order to profit and to take advantage of this. The presence of the group throughout the entire value chain of LNG and its position as a market leader gives us competitive advantages and offers to us special opportunities.

We've signed a variety of contracts to sell LNG. We've redeployed large quantities of LNG from the western world towards Asia Pacific, contracts with major players in China, Korea, Malaysia and India, accounting to a total of more than 8 million tons. We're currently involved in discussions as well with other potential buyers. In 2011, our external LNG sales rose significantly by about 30%, 48 deliveries, 25 of which was sent to the Asian market, so GDF SUEZ is very active in these markets. So, this is the success story over the last 18 months and will last into the future because we have the unique capacity to respond over a long-term basis to rising demand for LNG.

A recent study published by CERA forecasts an increase in demand for LNG from 2010 to 2016 of 71 million tons. 70% of this growth will happen in Asia, so it just shows that we are well-placed to take advantage of that since we're already there.

The group has the third largest LNG portfolio, 30% of that comes from long-term supply contracts. And we also have a very flexible fleet of 18 methane tankers that makes it possible for us not only to uphold our commitments but also to take advantage of market opportunities as they arise. So, the group has special competitive advantages, competitive edge. This makes it possible for us to roll out our long-term strategy with comfort.

That being said, we've decided to launch a short-term action plan across all of the group's business lines in order to make the group stronger because we are in a middle of an economic crisis in Europe. Nobody can really tell how long or how deep this crisis will be, and so we need to continue to develop the group's activities. And we're going to focus on four management priorities within the management of the group. We're going to be focusing, for example, on recurring net income. This will be the key indicator that we'll be using to measure managerial performance rather than focusing on EBITDA. In fact, tomorrow, we're going to be bringing together our 130 top managers from around the world in order to drive this point home to them.

Secondly, we have to increase our financial and strategic flexibility in the group. One of our greatest strengths has been not only our ability – or not only our sound financial structure in order to withstand the crisis. In fact, as of the end of 2008, 2009 (20:30) when the crisis first broke, we decided to strengthen our financial structure in order to protect the group. This is what's made it possible for us to contend with this second wave of crisis.

So, it's important to remain flexible. This is a categorical imperative for the group, both in strategic terms, we need to be able to be agile and as we've done with all of these different operations, International Power, CIC, LNG in Asia, and once the recovery kicks in, we'll be able – we'll be even stronger. We also need to optimize the creation of value on our industrial and commercial base as it currently exists. And we also need to strengthen synergies in the market for the future.

So, this plan actually bolsters the group's strategic vision and will make it easier for the group to deploy that vision. You've noted that amongst these priorities, we will be focusing more on the recurring net income. And this is a priority that has already been incorporated into the financial information that we will be sharing with you today.

In the past, we would always talk about EBITDA as the key indicator. But now we're going to be referring more – we're going to be referring more to the recurring net income indicator. And as of the 1st of January, this has already been factored into our management pay packages. And this is something that we've done also because the market has been asking us to do this. It enables us to focus more on the profitability or reflects the profitability of our strategy. And it should help us avoid the impact of changes in accounting practices in 2013 regarding proportional integration.

So, in 2012 we are looking at a stable picture with a recurring net income between €3.5 billion and €4 billion. The other indicators, we're going to have a CapEx – gross CapEx at about €11 billion and we shall be maintaining our – a credit rating and a net debt to EBITDA ratio less than or equal to 2.5 times and a stable or slightly increased dividend.
I'll now give the floor to Isabel so that she can take you through the financial figures for 2011. Thank you.

Good morning, everybody. I'm going to be spending most of my time talking about four fundamental issues. The two – the first two concern our performance in 2011 and of course I'd like to comment on that. And the other two concern our prospects for the medium term.

Now, our financial results 2011, this is the first message, very, very robust results despite the unfavorable impact that we've had on 2011, very, very unfavorable because of the climate. And you'll see, and I'll be showing you that despite that, our performance really has been excellent and our growth rates are very high. And this is the result of the strategy that we have been conducting. Second important message regarding 2011, you'll see that we have continued to strengthen our flexibility – our financial flexibility in the form of various projects, that I'll be telling you about. The other two issues concern the prospects forward.

And what I'll try and do is to show you that thanks to our business model which has made us one of the best-placed players in this industry because our business model actually has regulated and contracted assets of a large amount which means that we don't have to base – we don't have to change our (24:32) but also our merchant activity which allows us to make the most of the rebound. And thanks to that, our prospects for 2011 or 2012 to 2015 are very, very solid.

And lastly, I'd like to come back to our priorities, which Gérard Mestrallet has just talked about. And I think that these are the best priorities and strategies that we can have in the situation we're living. So first of all, our performance in 2011. Let me run through this slide, the changes in our EBITDA between 2010 and 2011. Now, you are familiar with these figures. I think they illustrate growth in EBITDA, large growth of more than €1.5 billion. And you can see there the 9.5% growth that Gérard Mestrallet has just mentioned. This 2011 performance was characterized by two major events, first of all, the climate and secondly, the acquisition of International Power.

Climate, first of all. Now, the climate impact when you compare performance in 2011, 2010 is a negative because although 2011 was a very, very hot year, specialists have been telling us that the climate scenario had 1% chances of happening. Well, 2010, in fact, was very cold. And when you accumulate the impact on accounts of this difference in climate, the distortion in climate between 2010 and 2011, well, you can see the impact has been almost €900 million. And that impact has been concentrated on two business lines, France Energy and Infrastructure.

Second exceptional event, the acquisition in February of last year of International Power. Now, in our 2011 accounts, we have an impact over 11 months of the acquisition of International Power, which represents €1.3 billion. Apart from those two exceptional events, our growth rate in EBITDA would be 5.8%.

Now, how is it broken down? Well, let me comment on this graph moving from the left to the right. Now, the energy – the French Energy business line as you can see – Energy France, as you can see, there is an EBITDA which has increased slightly. But nevertheless, it has gone up despite the major impact in 2011 of non-application of gas rates in France. And if you compare the 2011 rates and the ones in 2010, well, you can see that there was a negative impact of €350 million. And you've got all of the details in the appendices.

Now, that negative impact was partly offset by the fact that we now – since we signed in April 2010 a public service contract, we now have the margins for commercialization when it comes to gas sales activities. The impact for full year 2011 for those new margins make a difference compared to 2010 and represent €120 million. The other positive effect is the full year effect of the – going online in 2010 of additional generation capacity, wind power and also heat power or gas power. And lastly, the last thing which has allowed the French Energy business line to do well is the Efficio plan. It's our cost optimization plan.

Let me now move on to Europe and International. I should point out here that this is shown to you – taking in on board the old operational structure of the group. Later on, I'll give you the impact when it comes to the new breakdown of our group.

Now, first of all, we've got European activities. And you can see that those European activities have slightly dropped in 2011, about €50 million drop which is actually nevertheless good performance given the price context that we had in Europe in 2011.

Now, the price context was extremely flat, if I can put it like that. And since in 2010 we had – we were still feeling the impact of our hedging policy, very high prices that we had in the previous year, we've actually seen prices drop between 2010, 2011.

So, this good performance in the European Energy and International Energy, I think it's important to bear in mind. And of course, International, what I mean by that is International Power, basically, has seen huge organic growth, more than €350 million in growth linked to our South American business, particularly Brazil. Thanks in particular to the coming on the line of our first generation products in Estreito. That's a huge dam in Brazil.

Enormous growth in North America as well, driven in particular by the huge contribution of the LNG activity. Now, Hungary, let me move on. We're moving on sorry, to Global Gas & LNG. Now, this business line, the 3G as we often call it, covered three business lines' activities and let me run through them all. First activity, supply of gas; and the second, LNG; and the third, E&P.

Now, first of all, supply and sales of gas. This was characterized last year by a gas oil spread which was very high. But I should point out that thanks to price overhauling policy with our long-term contractors, our portfolio for supply and provision of gas has remained pretty much level, slightly increased in 2011. Same for 2012, given this policy that we have introduced, and which is clearly paying off with good results when it comes to price revision.

So, gas supply business, LNG as a business grew as well in 2011. And E&P also grew given the volume that we're talking about, there's been a ramp-up in (31:25) platform in Norway and also because of the very, very high oil prices in 2011. In euros, the oil prices went from €60 on average to €80 on average in 2011.

Infrastructure now, that's the next bar in the chart. Now, infrastructure is growing, as I said earlier, the climate of course has been – in fact at the time, it has been neutralized in this bar chart. But the drop in sales of French storage capacity was more than offset by two events or effects. First of all, the coming into line of Fos Cavaou last year. And that generated a lot of business for all of 2011, and also the acquisition – storage acquisition in Germany.

Services did very well as well, thanks to a positive contribution from all of the business units in services, so very, very good operational performance. And also thanks to successful acquisition of various heat networks in France and abroad.

Environment, SUEZ ENVIRONMENT, yesterday, the results were published, robust results with an increase in the EBITDA of nearly 7%. And I suggest that you look at the details that we provided yesterday by Jean-Louis Chaussade and his staff.

So in conclusion, I would say that despite the weather which actually played against us – I mean it was very, very exceptional weather. Hey, you have to go back a lot of – quite a few years to find a similar type of year. But despite that, the EBITDA growth was really very strong. And as Gérard Mestrallet said earlier on, if we rewrite the performance by wiping out the climate performance and the price performance, the tariff performance, which is what our reference line is, and our EBITDA for 2011 is about €17.4 billion.

Let me now give you some information about the other sections of the financial results. Now, the net current income of the group – group share stands at €3.455 billion in 2011. And that's characterized enormously, or marked by the weather and the tariff impact. Of course, they had a far harder effect on the net income than the EBITDA. And if we process those impacts, then you have considerable stability when it comes to the net current income group share in 2011 compared to 2010. I should point out that 2011 in certain ways was a very exceptional year. Various specific events have to be noted.

Now, the first thing is the depreciation and amortization. That stood in 2011 at €7.1 billion. So, huge increase compared to the previous year. And, of course, you can see the impact there of the acquisition of International Power. And you can also see the impact of the rolling out of new units and power stations. I should say that when you look at the PPA impact, there's a one-off effect of about more than €100 million which of course has an effect on the balance sheet or the financial exercise and the depreciation, amortissements (sic) [amortization] for 2011.

Now, the capital gains of assets shedding were about €1.5 billion. If you reprocess those figures, because of climate and if you also factor in the one-off impact of D&A well, then you have a margin rate which is stable between 2010 and 2011. In other words, we're not seeing some kind of twisting of our profitability or skewing of our profitability in net current income.

Now, the (35:54) gap is stable in 2011. It stands at roughly €700 million. The largest part being of course the spin off capital gains linked to the portfolio optimization. But I'll come back to that later on.

Our financial income – income from operating activities or financial results I should say, €2.6 billion, an increase obviously compared to the previous year. The financial burden has increased. It's increased quite simply and this is because of the increase in the debt – the gross debt because of the acquisition of Power. If we were looking at it on a pro forma basis, taking into account this acquisition, then we would have a financial debt of €2.9 billion. So, you can see we've already been working hard on financial synergy and working in general in order to optimize our financial results.

Tax now, tax increased this year, and this is linked to the development of E&P activities in Norway. You know of course, that those activities are far more taxed than the average of our business lines in the group. Minority stakes have increased also, and there of course you have the IP effect, the major effect, but there's also the effect of strategic partnerships that we have signed in 2011 and that appear for part of the year in our financial results. So, net income group share is €4 billion in 2011. Gérard Mestrallet has already said the group wants now to concentrate in the next few years on growth of this recurrent net income group share. We want it to be a key indicator of our performance and our prospects in the group.

I'd now like to talk about those aspects which make up our balance sheet and give you some information which will allow you to gauge the robustness of this balance sheet and the flexibility – the financial flexibility of this group and we decided to continue to work on this area.

Now, you can see that in 2011, cash – free cash flow was very, very high. An increase – a huge increase, I should say, actually more than the EBITDA mainly because the specific – the free cash flow. Dividends stable, €3.3 billion. Our investments, as Gérard Mestrallet has said, around €11 billion – about €10.7 billion. So, in 2011, the investments are very high as they were before. Now, the spinoffs have provided cash to the tune of €6.3 billion. We often talk of the net debt effect of our spinoffs which is high but this is just the cash effect of spinoffs.

Net debt, you can see, pretty extraordinary figures, €33 billion in 2010, €41.6 billion after the acquisition of International Power, and at the end of the year, €37.6 billion. So, when you look at the ratio or the gearing, I should say, and that's how we make our commitments. Well, you can see that that gearing has gone from 2.2 times in 2010 to 2.25 times pro forma, verging on the limits I told you. And then, one year later – less than one year, it has come down to the point of departure.

Now, I want to be fully transparent with you. I'd like to say that these figures worked out on the basis of the net debt and you have all of these mentioned in the appendices which allow you to understand this. We have decided in actual fact to exclude from our net debt the derivatives which every year are calculated at market value and which were booked into our net debt in the past, but which obviously nothing to do with the burden of that net debt in the future.

So, what we've been doing as indeed almost everybody else has been doing, was done in order to reduce the volatility of the net debt and to make it far more easy to interpret and make it easier to follow the changes and pro forma IP of course 2010, as I said, well we started with €40.16 billion (sic) [€41.6 billion]. At the end of 2011, we're down to €37.6 billion, so €4 billion of less net debt. In the former definition, you would have seen exactly the same thing and the drop would have been €3.7 billion just to be perfectly clear about it.

Okay. Now, what I'd like to do is to give you some information about spin-off program or disposal program. You'll remember that we announced at the beginning of last year a disposal program for three years to the tune of €10 billion. Where are we at the end of this first year? Well, you can see that we have done two-thirds of the spin-offs. The overall impact stands at €6.6 billion for the spin-offs. You know that these transactions – there are eight transactions in all, which were carried out in 2011. And I think one can rank them into two groups, really. The strategic partnerships which have been developed on E&P and gas transport and to do CIC on one hand, and then there's a consortium, CDC/CNP on the other hand. Also, we have spin-offs of certain business lines which are not strategic or we don't consider them to be strategic. Now, the full-year impact of these parts of the program, which has only been achieved in our spin-off program stands at €400 million of EBITDA and about €200 million of net recurring income.

And obviously, we are going to continue this program of spin-offs. We're in a very comfortable position and we can now conduct this. We don't have to be overhasty. We can take it slowly and continue to grow – develop it over the next two years and to roll out this program that we've begun. And we've ready got in mind some specific assets. And I think that soon, we're going to be able to announce quite a few operations.

Next slide, please. I'd like to say a couple of things about our cash flow now. You can see at the bottom left here that we have strong liquidity, €27 billion and cash more than €15 billion – nearly €16 billion in cash at the end of 2011, which means that we really are covered if there's any problem regarding cash availability in the next few years. And you can also see that the group's signature is greatly appreciated by the market. We, in 2011, as in the past, in fact, have undertaken quite a lot of operations on the bond market. We had the first issuance of – in history, I think over in 100 years and again in the second part of the year, we had bond issuances on the euro market and the UK market to the tune of – well for the entire year, more than €3 billion. And you can see that our debt maturity – our net debt maturity is more than 11 years now whereas in the past it was between six years and seven years in 2008. And you also know – I stress this because it's very important in our strategy. You know that our credit rating is very, very good with S&P and Moody's.

What I'd like to do now is to talk to you about future prospects. Now perhaps I could stress one thing, the balance that we have in this group. And I'd like to explain to you that if we had to rank our business line or group them into two parts; the contracted and regulated business lines on one hand, and the merchant, what I call merchant activities, on the other hand. Then you'd see that more than half of our EBITDA in actual fact is based on contracted and tariff-regulated businesses.

I'm thinking of infrastructure here. I'm thinking of some of storage activities not in France, but in Germany in particular. It's also the case for electricity generation in certain countries, particularly in Latin America, in the Middle East, and it applies also to some of our LNG business. As we've heard, these are contracted on a multi-year basis and also applies to services; both energy services but also environmental services. And it's on that part of our business that we have planned to really invest as much as we can in terms of CapEx for development. And that's where we're going to be creating value, thanks to those investments.

And then turning to the other group, on the left of this slide, you have what I call the businesses which are exposed to volatility in market prices. Most of our businesses there are energy businesses in Europe. Well, that's the case. I'm not talking of renewable growth. It's true for E&P which are very exposed to price fluctuation, particularly for oil. And in fact, they were favorably impacted by that price (46:08) last year. Also, to certain extent for LNG and also for gas storage in France.
